XXX* ABOUT THE POET
Bait Crane Bora 1899
med 1932
Bart Crane lived a brief, tragic life. After an unhappy childhood, he
left high school and wandered restlessly until he reached Hew York City, He
seemed to find there an agreeable atmosphere in which to write. A collection
of his poems--White Buil&Lngs--appeared in 1926. But it was not until 1930
with the publication of his poem "Brooklyn 3gx± Bridge" that his reputation
as a brilliant poet was made.
Acute depression, feelings of failure and other personal problems
plagued Crane throughout his life, and ultimately affected his work. In 1932,
he traveled to Mexico, hoping that the change in environment would give him
new inspiration. It was during the return vopage that he drowned himself at
the age of thirty-three.
Crane wrote in blank verse and his work seerafid to have the immediacy of
actual experience. He suggested his themes rather than stated them outright,
and his poems embody the kind of artistic shorthand that is characteristic of
much modern painting and music. His skilled use of lmageiy--reminiBcerit of
the Symbolist school of poetry—and his selection of evocative words give his
work great emotional appeal.

These are lifeless remnants of sea week and shellfish which once thrived
in the sea. All the words refer to the children's playthings which—
unrealized by the boys—are things which have once been living but are now
larked by death.
cordage
Shis word has the denotations of ropes used on a ship. Thus it is
specific in meaning and is infrequently used in other contexts. The
connotation is strength, easy movement, slimness, suppleness—characteristics
which the bodies of the children have also.
frisk
Ohis verb is frequently employed in describing the movements of young
animals. A lamb or colt (young horse) may frisk in a meadow. It suggests
playfulness and light-heartedness. Frisky (adj.) is commonly used.
